image.altText: Wayne Butcher looking at camera

items.synopsis: After voting in favour of the First Nations Treaty Institute and truth-telling inquiry that passed parliament five months ago the Queensland Liberal National Party yesterday withdrew its support for a Path to Treaty.

title.children: 'Double whammy' for Indigenous community groups in Queensland 'kicked while we're down'

image.altText: Medicare

items.synopsis: You may have received a text or email in recent weeks from your GP asking you to register for something called MyMedicare. So how does the scheme work and is it worth signing up?

title.children: The launch of MyMedicare has left many of us confused. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Joe Biden sits at his Oval Office desk and speaks.

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden makes a rare prime-time national address in which he asks congress for more support for Israel and Ukraine, saying the world is "facing an inflection point in history". Follow live.

title.children: 'Facing inflection point': Biden gives rare prime-time address in bid for Ukraine, Israel funds

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Biden closes out his address by saying: "We cannot and will not let terrorists like Hamas and tyrants like Putin win. "I refuse to let that happen. "And in moments like these we have to remind and remember who we are. We are the United States of America. The United States of America. "And there is nothing, nothing, beyond our capacity if we do it together. "My fellow Americans, thank you for your time. May God bless you all. And may God protect our troops."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: America 'cannot and will not' let 'terrorists, tyrants' win

children.content: Mr Biden closes out his address by saying: "We cannot and will not let terrorists like Hamas and tyrants like Putin win.
"I refuse to let that happen.
"And in moments like these we have to remind and remember who we are. We are the United States of America. The United States of America.
"And there is nothing, nothing, beyond our capacity if we do it together.
"My fellow Americans, thank you for your time. May God bless you all. And may God protect our troops."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Mr Biden is recounting his visit to Ukraine with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to mark the one-year anniversary of war. "With me was just a small group of security personnel and a few advisers," he says. "But when I exited the train and met President Zelenskyy, I did not feel alone. "I was bringing with me the idea of America, the promise of America, to the people who were fighting for the same things we fought for 250 years ago — freedom, independence, self-determination. "And as I walked through Kyiv with President Zelenskyy, with air raid sirens sounding in the distance, I felt something I have always believed: We are stronger than ever before. America is big to the world. Still. Still."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: America 'stronger than ever before'

children.content: Mr Biden is recounting his visit to Ukraine with President Volodymyr Zelenskyy to mark the one-year anniversary of war.
"With me was just a small group of security personnel and a few advisers," he says.
"But when I exited the train and met President Zelenskyy, I did not feel alone.
"I was bringing with me the idea of America, the promise of America, to the people who were fighting for the same things we fought for 250 years ago — freedom, independence, self-determination.

"And as I walked through Kyiv with President Zelenskyy, with air raid sirens sounding in the distance, I felt something I have always believed: We are stronger than ever before. America is big to the world. Still. Still."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "When I was in Israel yesterday, I said that when Americans experienced the hell of 9/11, we felt enraged as well but we sought and got justice and we made mistakes," Mr Biden says. "So I cautioned the government of Israel not to be blinded by rage. "And here in America, let us not forget who we are. "We reject all forms, all forms, of hate. Whether against Muslims, Jews or anyone." He added he would ask congress to send Ukraine the weapons to defend itself from "Putin's brutality". "What would happen if we walked away? We are the essential nation."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden: 'We reject all forms of hate'

children.content: "When I was in Israel yesterday, I said that when Americans experienced the hell of 9/11, we felt enraged as well but we sought and got justice and we made mistakes," Mr Biden says.

props.alt: Biden gestures with his hands as he sits at his desk.

children.content: (Reuters: Jonathan Ernst/Pool)
"So I cautioned the government of Israel not to be blinded by rage.
"And here in America, let us not forget who we are.
"We reject all forms, all forms, of hate. Whether against Muslims, Jews or anyone."
He added he would ask congress to send Ukraine the weapons to defend itself from "Putin's brutality".
"What would happen if we walked away? We are the essential nation."

image.altText: Angus Campbell in ceremonial miliatry dress holds a sword

items.synopsis: Veterans claim they have uncovered evidence of the "systematic abuse" of Australia's honours and awards system that has allowed senior commanders, including current Defence Chief General Angus Campbell, to be wrongly awarded "distinguished service" medals for decades.

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

image.altText: Stephen Edwards with parents David and Nelda

image.altText: A woman standing at her kitchen bench with a sweet potato on a chopping board.

title.children: Sara was skipping meals and eating instant noodles to save money. Then she was diagnosed with malnutrition

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: Local shares are down in early trade after a slide on Wall Street overnight. Liontown Resources is the biggest mover, down 35 per cent after a multi-billion-dollar takeover bid failed. Follow live.

title.children: Liontown Resources shares in freefall, ASX opens lower after Wall Street slide

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: RBA governor Michelle Bullock and assistant governor Christopher Kent are scheduled for testimony at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee next Thursday. The hearing will provide a better indication of whether the Reserve Bank will raise rates on Melbourne Cup Day. The September quarter CPI data, due for release on Wednesday, will also feed into the decision. Most economists are expecting annual inflation to continue easing from 6 per cent in the June quarter to somewhere between 5 per cent and 5.4 per cent. Current market pricing has the odds of a November interest rate rise by the Reserve Bank at about 25 per cent. But an inflation number above those forecasts would raise the chance of another rate hike in the lead up to the Christmas holidays.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is the RBA likely to raise rates on Cup Day?

children.content: RBA governor Michelle Bullock and assistant governor Christopher Kent are scheduled for testimony at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee next Thursday.
The hearing will provide a better indication of whether the Reserve Bank will raise rates on Melbourne Cup Day.
The September quarter CPI data, due for release on Wednesday, will also feed into the decision.
Most economists are expecting annual inflation to continue easing from 6 per cent in the June quarter to somewhere between 5 per cent and 5.4 per cent.
Current market pricing has the odds of a November interest rate rise by the Reserve Bank at about 25 per cent.
But an inflation number above those forecasts would raise the chance of another rate hike in the lead up to the Christmas holidays.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The share price of Australian lithium developer Liontown Resources has tanked this morning, down up to 35%. It's all because yesterday it announced a billion-dollar funding package for its flagship Kathleen Valley lithium project, planning to raise $376 million in a discounted share placement and $760 million via debt. Funding plans had to change because earlier in the week US-based Albemarle Corp withdrew its $6.6 billion buyout bid, citing 'growing complexities.' The withdrawal came days after Hancock Prospecting (Gina Rinehart's company!) raised its stake to 19.9% of Liontown (which would have been enough to block the Albemarle bid of $3 per share). The Kathleen Valley project is widely regarded as one of the world's top five lithium projects, and Liontown has already signed deals to supply Ford Motor and Tesla. Here's a chart showing you Liontown's shareprice over the last 10 days. Talk about a slide!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is going on with Liontown Resources?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, the local share markets have opened lower this morning. It comes after all three major US indices fell overnight. The ASX 200 is down -1.15% to 6,901 at 10:30am (AEDT). The broader All Ordinaries index is also down about the same, to 7,092 points. Only one sector is currently (slightly) up: that's energy (+0.23%). The other 10 sectors are lower, led by basic materials (-1.55%), academic and educational services (-1.42%) and real estate (-1.35%). Liontown Resources shares have tanked as much as 35% in early trade, their worst intraday drop since 2015. Shares had been suspended after US giant Albemarle withdrew its $6.6 billion takeover offer earlier this week, citing 'growing complexities.' The top movers: Bluescope Steel (+1.5%) Healius Ltd (+1.4%) Santos Ltd (+1.1%) Paladin Energy (+0.8%) Northern Star Resources (+0.75%) The bottom movers: Liontown Resources (-33%) Insignia Financial (-8%) Telix Pharmaceuticals (-5.3%) Netwealth Group (-4.5%) Life360 (-4.1%)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Markets open lower
